definitions: allow something to fall by releasing hold or support
decrease suddenly and significantly in amount level or value
deliver or leave someone or something at a particular place
stop doing pursuing or discussing something completely and suddenly
fall down suddenly from exhaustion or loss of consciousness
examples: She accidentally dropped her phone on the concrete floor
The children dropped their toys when dinner was ready
Stock prices dropped dramatically after the announcement yesterday
The temperature dropped twenty degrees within an hour
Could you drop me off at the train station?
The courier dropped the package at our front door
They decided to drop the lawsuit against their neighbor
She dropped her plans to study medicine last year
The marathon runner dropped from exhaustion near the finish
He worked until he literally dropped from fatigue

definitions: kick a ball as it drops from the hands before touching ground
execute a wrestling move jumping and kicking with both feet extended
examples: The rugby player dropkicked the ball between the goal posts
He perfectly dropkicked the football from thirty yards away
The wrestler dropkicked his opponent across the ring dramatically
She executed a spectacular dropkick during the match yesterday

definitions: die from being unable to breathe underwater or in liquid
cover or submerge something completely in water or other liquid
make a sound inaudible by producing a louder noise simultaneously
become completely overwhelmed by an intense emotion or difficult situation
examples: The sailor drowned when his boat capsized during the storm
Three people nearly drowned in the flooding last week
Heavy rains drowned the crops in the low-lying fields
She drowned the vegetables in too much salad dressing
The loud music drowned out their conversation completely yesterday
Traffic noise drowned his voice during the phone call
He was drowning in debt after losing his job
She felt like she was drowning in responsibilities lately

definitions: do hard menial or monotonous work for long periods without recognition
examples: She drudged in the factory for twenty years straight
The interns drudged through mountains of paperwork every day

definitions: administer medicine or drugs to someone for medical treatment purposes
add drugs secretly to food or drink to stupefy or poison
examples: The veterinarian drugged the horse before the surgical procedure
Doctors drugged him heavily to manage the severe pain
Someone drugged her drink at the party last night
The kidnapper drugged his victims before transporting them elsewhere

definitions: play a drum or drums by striking with sticks or hands
make a continuous rhythmic noise by repeated tapping or beating
instill knowledge or ideas through constant forceful repetition into someone
examples: She drums in a local jazz band every weekend
The children drummed enthusiastically during the music class yesterday
Rain drummed steadily on the metal roof all night
He nervously drummed his fingers on the table top
The teacher drummed the multiplication tables into their heads
His parents drummed the importance of education into him

definitions: remove moisture from something using heat air or absorbent material
lose moisture and become free from water or liquid content
undergo treatment to stop drinking alcohol or recover from alcoholism
examples: She dried the dishes with a clean kitchen towel
The sun dried the wet clothes in two hours
The paint should dry completely before applying another coat
The puddles dried quickly in the hot summer sun
He finally decided to dry out at a rehabilitation center
She has been trying to dry out for months

definitions: give an unofficial name or nickname to someone or something formally
add a different language soundtrack or sound effects to a film
make a copy of a recording onto another medium or format
examples: The media dubbed him the king of pop music
They dubbed the scandal Watergate after the hotel name
The studio dubbed the Japanese film into English yesterday
They carefully dubbed new dialogue over the original soundtrack
He dubbed the album from vinyl onto a cassette
The engineer dubbed multiple copies of the master recording

definitions: lower the head or body quickly to avoid something dangerous
avoid or evade a responsibility duty or difficult question deliberately
push someone or something briefly under water and raise again
examples: She ducked just as the ball flew over her
Everyone ducked when they heard the explosion nearby yesterday
The politician ducked every question about the scandal persistently
He always ducks his responsibilities at work these days
The kids ducked each other in the swimming pool
She playfully ducked him under the water once quickly

definitions: fight a formal prearranged combat between two people with weapons
examples: The two officers dueled at dawn to settle their dispute
In the past gentlemen dueled over matters of honor

definitions: make a blade edge or point less sharp through use or deliberately
make something less intense bright or clear in quality or feeling
make or become less interesting exciting or intellectually stimulating over time
examples: Cutting cardboard quickly dulled the scissors blade significantly yesterday
Years of use had dulled the kitchen knife considerably
The medication dulled his pain but made him drowsy
Clouds dulled the bright sunshine this afternoon significantly today
Routine work gradually dulled his enthusiasm for the job
The repetitive lectures dulled the students interest in history

definitions: get rid of something by throwing or dropping it carelessly
end a romantic relationship with someone suddenly and without consideration
sell goods quickly at a much lower price than normal value
transfer or copy data from one storage location to another quickly
examples: Someone illegally dumped old furniture by the roadside yesterday
They dumped toxic waste into the river at night
She dumped her boyfriend after discovering his lies yesterday
He got dumped by text message which really hurt
The company dumped excess inventory at discount prices quickly
Foreign manufacturers were accused of dumping cheap steel here
The programmer dumped the database to a backup file
Can you dump those files onto my hard drive?

definitions: dip or immerse something briefly into liquid then remove it quickly
score in basketball by jumping and thrusting the ball down through the hoop
examples: She dunked her cookie in milk before eating it
He dunked the bread into the soup bowl carefully
The player dunked the ball with incredible force yesterday
She can dunk despite being shorter than most players

definitions: deceive or trick someone into believing or doing something foolish
examples: The scammer duped elderly people out of their savings
She was duped into signing the fraudulent contract yesterday

definitions: make an exact copy or copies of something using equipment or methods
do something again unnecessarily when it has already been done properly
examples: Please duplicate these documents for everyone attending the meeting
The machine can duplicate keys in just two minutes
We shouldn't duplicate efforts that another team already completed
The research duplicated work done five years ago unnecessarily

definitions: remove dust and dirt from furniture surfaces using a cloth or tool
sprinkle a powdery substance lightly and evenly over something surface area
examples: She dusts the living room furniture every Saturday morning
The housekeeper dusted all the shelves and picture frames
The baker dusted the cake with powdered sugar generously
She dusted flour on the counter before rolling dough

definitions: cause something to seem small or insignificant by comparison with something larger
examples: The skyscraper dwarfed all the surrounding buildings completely yesterday
His achievements dwarf those of his contemporaries by far

definitions: live in or at a specified place as a resident permanently
think speak or write at length about something particularly unpleasant persistently
examples: They dwell in a cottage by the sea peacefully
Many species dwell in the rainforest canopy year-round permanently
Don't dwell on your mistakes from the past forever
She tends to dwell on negative thoughts too much

definitions: gradually become smaller fewer or less in size number or strength
examples: Their savings dwindled rapidly after he lost his job
The crowd dwindled to just a handful of people

definitions: change the color of something using a special liquid substance permanently
examples: She dyed her hair blonde for the summer vacation
They dyed the fabric a deep purple color yesterday

definitions: blow up or destroy something using dynamite explosive material forcefully
examples: The construction crew dynamited the old bridge yesterday morning
Miners dynamited through solid rock to create the tunnel

definitions: receive money as payment for work or services provided regularly
gain or deserve something through effort achievement or particular qualities displayed
examples: She earns a good salary working at the bank
He earned fifty dollars babysitting last night for neighbors
The team earned their victory through hard work yesterday
She earned respect by always keeping her promises consistently

definitions: cover or heap up plants or vegetables with soil for protection
connect an electrical device to the ground for safety purposes effectively
examples: The gardener earthed up the potatoes to protect them
We need to earth these plants before winter arrives
The electrician properly earthed all the electrical equipment yesterday
Make sure to earth the washing machine for safety

definitions: make something less difficult painful or troublesome for someone gradually
move slowly and carefully into or out of a position or place
become less severe intense or serious in degree or effect gradually
examples: The medication eased her pain within minutes of taking
New technology has eased the workload for employees significantly
She carefully eased herself into the hot bath water
He eased the car out of the tight parking space
The tension in the room eased after his apology
Traffic usually eases after nine in the morning weekdays

definitions: put food into the mouth chew and swallow it for nourishment
gradually destroy erode or use up something through continuous action persistently
cause persistent anxiety or emotional distress to someone about something troubling
examples: The family eats dinner together every evening at six
She ate the sandwich quickly during her lunch break
Rust is eating away at the metal fence posts
Inflation eats into our savings every year significantly now
Guilt was eating at him for months after that
What's eating you today that makes you so upset?

definitions: flow back or recede as the tide goes out from the shore
gradually decrease decline or decay in strength or intensity over time
examples: The tide ebbs twice daily along this coastal area
The water ebbed revealing shells on the beach sand
His enthusiasm for the project slowly ebbed over time
Public interest in the scandal ebbed after several weeks

definitions: produce a sound that reflects off surfaces and repeats after delay
repeat someone's words or opinions especially to express agreement or emphasis
have characteristics that recall or are reminiscent of something else strongly
examples: Her voice echoed through the empty hallway eerily yesterday
The mountains echo with birdsong every morning at dawn
The students echoed their teacher's words in unison today
Politicians often echo each other's talking points repeatedly nowadays
The design echoes classical architecture from ancient Rome beautifully
His poetry echoes the style of earlier romantic writers

definitions: obscure the light from one celestial body by another passing between
be much more successful important or impressive than someone or something else
examples: The moon will eclipse the sun tomorrow afternoon completely
Clouds eclipsed the stars for most of the night
Her achievements eclipsed those of all previous champions completely
The new product quickly eclipsed its competitors in sales

definitions: move in a circular motion like water or air forming small whirlpools
examples: Leaves eddied in the wind around the courtyard yesterday
The water eddied near the rocks creating dangerous currents

definitions: move slowly and carefully in a particular direction or position gradually
provide or form a border or edge to something decoratively or functionally
defeat someone by a small margin or gain a slight advantage over
examples: She edged toward the door trying not to be noticed
The car edged through the narrow alley very carefully
They edged the garden path with decorative stones yesterday
Lace edged the hem of her wedding dress beautifully
Our team edged the opponents by just one point
She edged him out for the promotion last month

definitions: revise and correct written material for accuracy clarity and improvement carefully
prepare written material for publication by selecting arranging and modifying content
examples: She carefully edited her essay before submitting it yesterday
The author spent months editing the manuscript for errors
He edits a major literary magazine in New York
She edited the anthology of contemporary poetry last year

definitions: give intellectual moral and social instruction to someone systematically over time
give someone information about a particular subject to increase awareness understanding
examples: The school educates children from ages five to eighteen
Parents must educate their children about online safety nowadays
The campaign educates voters about their constitutional rights effectively
Doctors should educate patients about treatment options available today

definitions: cause something to happen or come into being through deliberate action
examples: The new manager effected significant changes in company policy
They hope to effect a peaceful resolution soon today

definitions: encourage or urge someone to do something foolish or risky persistently
examples: His friends egged him on to jump off the cliff
Don't egg her on when she's already angry enough

definitions: force or throw something out suddenly or violently from within something
force someone to leave a place or position using authority or physical force
examples: The volcano ejected lava and ash high into the air
Press this button to eject the DVD from the player
Security ejected the troublemaker from the concert venue immediately
The pilot ejected from the plane just before it crashed

definitions: add more detail or information to something already said or written extensively
develop or work out something in detail and with great care methodically
examples: Could you elaborate on your proposal during the meeting?
She elaborated her theory with numerous examples and evidence
The architect elaborated the initial sketches into detailed blueprints
They elaborated a complex plan over several months carefully

definitions: push or strike someone with one's elbow to move past or get attention
examples: She elbowed her way through the crowded subway car
He accidentally elbowed me in the ribs while sleeping

definitions: choose someone for a position or office through a formal voting process
choose to do something or follow a particular course of action deliberately
examples: The citizens elected a new mayor last November overwhelmingly
The board elected her as chairperson by unanimous vote
Many students elect to study abroad during junior year
She elected to remain silent during the police questioning

definitions: supply electrical power to something or convert it to electrical operation
cause someone to feel sudden excitement shock or thrill with great intensity
examples: They plan to electrify the rural railway system soon
The company electrified all its delivery vehicles last year
Her performance electrified the audience completely last night yesterday
The announcement electrified the crowd at the rally instantly

definitions: raise or lift something up to a higher physical position or level
raise someone to a more important or impressive level rank or status
increase the level intensity or amount of something abstract or measurable significantly
examples: The nurse elevated his injured leg on several pillows
The platform elevates the speaker above the audience clearly
The company elevated her to senior vice president yesterday
His work elevated him to celebrity status almost overnight
Exercise elevates your heart rate and improves circulation significantly
The medication can elevate blood pressure in some patients

definitions: draw out or bring forth a response reaction or information from someone deliberately
examples: The comedian's jokes elicited laughter from the entire audience
Her questions failed to elicit any useful information yesterday

definitions: completely remove or get rid of something unwanted or unnecessary permanently
remove a competitor or team from further participation in a competition
murder someone especially as part of a political or criminal plan deliberately
examples: The company eliminated several redundant positions last quarter entirely
New technology has eliminated the need for manual filing
Our team was eliminated in the semifinal round yesterday
The judges eliminated three contestants from the show tonight
The spy was ordered to eliminate the foreign agent
Gang members eliminated their rival in a planned attack

definitions: make something longer in shape size or duration by stretching or extending
examples: The artist elongated the figure to create a dramatic effect
Heat causes metal to elongate slightly when measured precisely

definitions: run away secretly with a lover to get married without parental approval
examples: The young couple eloped to Las Vegas last weekend
They decided to elope rather than plan a big wedding

definitions: make something clear by explaining it in detail with careful analysis thoroughly
examples: The professor elucidated the complex theory using simple examples
Could you elucidate your position on this issue please?

definitions: escape from or avoid someone or something by speed or cleverness persistently
fail to be attained achieved or understood by someone despite efforts made
examples: The criminal eluded police for several months before capture
She eluded her pursuers by hiding in the crowd
Success has eluded him throughout his entire career unfortunately
The meaning of the poem eludes most readers completely today

definitions: send a message or document to someone using electronic mail system digitally
examples: Please email me the report by Friday afternoon latest
She emails her clients every Monday with weekly updates

definitions: originate from or be produced by a source spreading outward from it
examples: A strange smell emanated from the old basement yesterday
Confidence emanated from her during the important presentation today

definitions: officially ban trade or commercial activity with a particular country or group
examples: The UN embargoed arms sales to the conflict region
Several nations embargoed oil imports from that country yesterday

definitions: go on board a ship aircraft or other vehicle for a journey
begin a new project or course of action with enthusiasm and determination
examples: Passengers embarked at the port early this morning today
The troops embarked on the transport ships at dawn
She embarked on a new career in her fifties
They embarked upon an ambitious renovation project last year
